item.title: The Next Decade of Bandwidth - Part I
item.description: The recent collapse of the AT&T and T-Mobile merger, while seemingly a win for consumers against a potential monopoly, wasn’t truly about market control. Even if the merger succeeded, Verizon and Sprint would still offer competition. The real issue was bandwidth. The evidence is clear: immediately after the deal failed, AT&T purchased $1.9 billion in spectrum from Qualcomm with FCC approval, while Verizon, after acquiring $3.6 billion worth of spectrum from Comcast and Time Warner Cable, also bought $315 million of spectrum from Cox.
